image.altText: a priest wearing glasses and a woman reverend look at the camera

items.synopsis: Twenty-four hours after a horror bus crash killed 10 wedding guests, there have been prayers, candles and a guernsey tribute.

title.children: Close-knit Hunter Valley community pulls together after tragic wedding bus crash

image.altText: A man in the suit on the left looks happy with himself and a man in the right in a suit looks up up at the gallery

items.synopsis: Transparency and integrity experts criticise the Tasmanian government's reliance on claims of cabinet confidentiality to avoid releasing departmental advice about its controversial plan to build a stadium on Hobart's waterfront.

title.children: Transparency experts slam Tasmanian government secrecy over planned stadium

image.altText: Fiona Mardling smiling in a portrait, wearing a blue clinic uniform and a stethscope around her neck.

items.synopsis: Nurses outside of hospitals say they are not being used to their full capacity, with one group blaming Medicare rules for holding them back.

title.children: This nurse has three decades of experience, but Medicare says her time is worth $12.70

image.altText: A crowd of customers are a cafe counter, as one person serves coffee, while others look at their phones.

items.synopsis: Finger-pointing over what or who is responsible for inflation is gaining momentum. But the cause of and solutions for the issue are very hard to identify, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The battle between wages and profits heats up, as many scramble to understand the cause of inflation

image.altText: A Caucasian woman in a pink top and black jacket, speaks at the podium of parliament, with her party sitting behind her.

items.synopsis: Federal Housing Minister Julie Collins has offered to amend the Housing Australia Future Fund legislation to guarantee yearly spending in return for Senate crossbench support.

title.children: Federal government shifts on key housing policy – but Greens remain opposed

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

items.synopsis: With only 24 hours in a day, researchers have crunched the numbers and worked out what the average global human day looks like.

title.children: A day in the life: Researchers have worked out an average 24 hours for a human in the 21st century

image.altText: a bunch of flowers on the floor

items.synopsis: A 58-year-old bus driver has been charged over the crash that killed 10 people and left more than 20 injured in the NSW Hunter region on Sunday night.

title.children: Bus driver charged over crash that killed 10 people in Hunter Valley

image.altText: Three police officers examine the underside of a bus that has turned on its side.

items.synopsis: Forensic and traffic police are piecing together the events of a fatal bus crash in NSW's Hunter Valley, which has claimed the lives of 10 wedding-goers.

title.children: What we know about how a bus carrying more than 30 wedding guests crashed in the NSW Hunter

image.altText: One hand on a laptop's trackpad while another hand holds a credit card

items.synopsis: Fraudulent sites are mimicking real brands, going as far as stealing logos and brand design. Melinda did the checks but they weren't enough — so here are the signs to look out for.

title.children: Melinda ordered $200 boots online. What arrived were $2 sunnies

image.altText: A group of soldiers and small frail children covered in blankets on the jungle floor

items.synopsis: The eldest child of the four siblings told her family their mother was alive for four days before she died from injuries in plane crash.

title.children: Rescued child says mother survived for days in jungle after plane crash

image.altText: A view showing the outside of the garden of the home where the shooting took place.

items.synopsis: An 11-year-old British girl is shot dead in the garden of her home in France, following a years-long dispute between neighbours over land.

title.children: British girl, 11, shot dead in family garden in western France over years-long dispute with neighbour

image.altText: Silvio Berlusconi looks into the distance.

items.synopsis: The controversial politician and media mogul has died in hospital in Milan after suffering from leukaemia for "some time".

title.children: Former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi dies, aged 86

image.altText: Woman with grey hair and glasses listens to colleagues at a meeting

items.synopsis: Generational stereotypes can sound convincing, but in the workplace they can become a pervasive form of ageism.

title.children: 'Lazy thinking': Why generational stereotypes do harm in the workplace

image.altText: Ben Stokes walks with the sun framing his head

items.synopsis: England have revitalised their Test team — and some would say the entire red-ball form of the sport — with their free hitting, fun loving style under new coach Brendon McCullum. But what is it about Bazball that has been so successful?

title.children: Australia set for first look at England's Bazball revolution

image.altText: smiling woman with two smiling young  boys

items.synopsis: Jacqueline Morton has four sustainable tiny homes on her 32-acre property, but the local council is kicking out the vulnerable residents living on her land.

title.children: Property owner blasts 'disgusting attitude' of Sunshine Coast Council as it evicts her tiny home residents

image.altText: Blurry screenshots of personal ID documents like passports, and other documents marked "confidential".

items.synopsis: The newest victims of a notorious Russian ransomware gang say they have been terrified by the latest cyber attack on an Australian bond broker that has billions of dollars under advice.

title.children: 'You have 3 days': Russian criminals post screenshots of passports to dark web after bond broker data breach

image.altText: Ukrainian serviceman sits atop a tank, amid Russia's attack on Ukraine, in Donetsk region.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says troops recaptured a fourth village from Russian forces in the south-east, where its forces have at last claimed gains in its long-anticipated counteroffensive.

title.children: Ukrainian troops retake villages while Russia says it repelled new offences

image.altText: Image of a customer using a tap-and-go credit card in a store.

items.synopsis: Business owners who have stopped accepting cash say it speeds up service and improves safety and security for staff, but some customers say it is their right to pay cash.

title.children: No law exists to stop businesses from refusing cash. Why do some people care so much?

image.altText: A man stands between two women. He's smiling. The women are pixelated.

items.synopsis: Concerned Catholics of Tasmania wants an independent investigation into Catholic Education Tasmania after its executive director apologised for inappropriate behaviour towards two staff members.

title.children: Concerned Catholics want investigation into allegations of inappropriate behaviour by head of catholic schools in Tasmania

image.altText: Three flight attendants — a man in a dark suit, and two women wearing red and black dresses — stand in a plane smiling.

items.synopsis: The airline is scrapping its gender-based uniform guidelines — and it's not the first, with many airlines having updated their rules to allow staff to show their authentic selves.

title.children: Qantas to allow flat shoes, make-up and long hair on crew of any gender — but what does this mean for inclusivity?

image.altText: A composite image of a bald PNG man with glasses wearing a grey suit and another PNG man wearing a grey cap

items.synopsis: Despite having to flee his home, Neville Devete says he has no regrets after sparking Papua New Guinea's biggest corruption investigation.

title.children: 'It was plainly corrupt': The man who helped take down one of PNG's biggest fraudsters

image.altText: A man speaks into a megaphone surrounded by journalists outside in PNG

items.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's former prime minister, Peter O'Neill, is charged with giving false evidence after a commission of inquiry recommends he be prosecuted.

title.children: Former PNG prime minister Peter O'Neill charged with giving false evidence at inquiry

image.altText: Headshots of a smiling man in a cap wearing glasses, and a woman wearing sunglasses

items.synopsis: A 23-year-old man who allegedly ran over and killed WA police officer Anthony Woods in Perth is set to be charged with his murder, as the constable's family remember him as "a devoted husband and loving son".

title.children: Police to lay upgraded murder charge over WA officer's death as 'shattered' family leads tributes

image.altText: Xavier Coates, wearing his Queensland State of Origin guernsey and a mouth guard, looks to the sky.

items.synopsis: Queensland coach Billy Slater has made three changes to the side who claimed victory in State of Origin I as the Maroons look to wrap up the series on home soil.

title.children: Injury-plagued Queensland recall three players for State of Origin II

image.altText: A young man runs away from the camera on a football field at night kicking a soccer ball. He is wearing a team uniform.

items.synopsis: Australian soccer's governing body is taking a cut from every local bet placed on games at all levels, including amateur suburban competitions.

title.children: 'It's disturbing': This suburban football club had no idea international gamblers could place bets on their games

image.altText: Woman toasting champagne at a wedding.

items.synopsis: A speech pathologist who has not been seen since the small boat she was travelling in capsized has been described as a tireless community worker.

title.children: Family heartbroken as search suspended for grandmother lost at sea

image.altText: Two you women stand in an alley holding vegetables

items.synopsis: Food waste is a big issue, especially when there is a cost-of-living crisis. And while "dumpster diving" is not encouraged, with strict guidelines, it is one of the ways Tasmanian volunteers are helping to keep people fed.

title.children: These women don't want good food wasted so even 'dumpster diving' is on the menu — to a point

image.altText: a medium sized yacht engulfed by flames

items.synopsis: Witnesses say the boat carrying tourists on a scuba trip was engulfed by flames in a matter of minutes.

title.children: British tourists missing after Red Sea boat fire

image.altText: Mayon volcano belches red-hot emissions down it's slope as seen from Legaspi, Albay province.

items.synopsis: The Philippines' most active volcano spews lava down its slopes, as thousands of villagers prepare to flee amid fears of life-threatening explosion.

title.children: Philippines volcano spews lava down slopes in gentle eruption putting thousands on alert

image.altText: Australian banknotes, mostly $50 bills, strewn over a flat surface.

items.synopsis: Almost 5 million Australians claimed work from home expenses last financial year, but the ATO has changed the methods you can use to claim tax deductions this tax time. Landlords renting out property and crypto investors are also under focus.

title.children: The ATO's changed the methods you can use to claim tax deductions for working from home

image.altText: A bearded man in a baseball cap

items.synopsis: Richmond player Marlion Pickett is granted bail after allegedly carrying out burglaries on commercial properties in which more than $380,000 was stolen.

title.children: Details revealed of Marlion Pickett's alleged involvement in theft of $380k from commercial premises as bail granted

image.altText: High pressure hoses blasting through the surface of a dried up dam

items.synopsis: Sibayne Stillwater sets up shop in Australia citing a "robust and high-quality mining industry" and strong opportunities as it shifts to green energy.

title.children: Global South African miner buys outback Queensland mine

image.altText: Black-and-white image of a man sunbaking on a beach.

items.synopsis: He was one of the most prolific Australian photographers of the 20th century, but these lesser-known Max Dupain works have escaped the public eye for decades.

title.children: He's best known for the Sunbaker, but one chapter of photographer Max Dupain's life remains largely forgotten
